element.description: Text at the top of the page, often containing titles, section names, or page numbers. Not to be confused with heading elements (h1-h6).
Text at the bottom of the page, often containing page numbers, copyright, or additional information.
Primary heading or document title. The most prominent heading on the page.
Section heading. Major divisions within the document.
Minor heading. Further subdivisions within subsections.
Body text content, typically arranged in paragraphs. The primary readable content of the document.
Text content positioned to the side of the main body, often containing supplementary information, tips, or related content.
Explanatory notes placed at the bottom of the page, referenced from the main text. Use the ref attribute to link to the source element.
Text accompanying images, tables, or figures, providing additional context or explanation. Use the ref attribute to link to the associated figure.
Visual content such as images, charts, diagrams, or flowcharts. Include caption for visible text and alt_text for accessibility description.
Textual content within tables, including headers and cell data.
A notable excerpt from the main text, often displayed prominently on the page.
Bulleted or numbered list content. Preserve list structure in the text.
Decorative or non-meaningful content that should be ignored by screen readers (e.g., background images, decorative lines, watermarks).
